Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 12 - The tale of the good-hearted tree
Every time that a buddha appears on earth, a tree of the  'good-hearted' kind springs up.
Manual - English: A falling large tree cuts off the river causing the danger of the flooding in one part of the city. Many men are pulling out the tree. A black snake emerges, but a young man with a turban cuts it at the waist with a sword. Devadetta shoots a goose down with an arrow. The Buddha heals the wound on the goose. The Buddha grabs the tree and throws it up in the air with one hand. The tree breaks into halves, with a piece fall on each side of the river.

Sun of Faith - English: And so it was that between Kapilavastu and Devadaha, on one of the banks of the river Rohitaka (Ro hi ta ka), a tree of that sort appeared.
In a single day it grew a hundred cubits.
If you wished to encircle one of its twigs with your fingers, you had to do it before the following daybreak.
Wait longer than that and no tool or weapon could make an impression on it—
even an outbreak of fire could not destroy it.
From time to time Rohitaka would burst its banks and wash away the soil covering the good-hearted tree's roots.
This happened so often that one day, during a raging tempest, the tree got uprooted and fell in such a way that it dammed up the river.
[The two cities' inhabitants felt the adverse effects of that:] Devadaha suffered from lack of water
and Kapilavastu had to endure flooding.
The villages organized crews to try to remove the tree. In vain. The trunk could not be dislodged.
King Suprabuddha sent off a messenger with the following letter for King Shuddhodana:
“You well know how strong your son is. Why don't you ask him to come and remove this tree?”
“I don't give orders to my son,” replied King Shuddhodana.
Chandaka, childhood friend and equerry of the prince, piped up: “Your Majesty, let me try. I'll arrange matters in such a way that he will undertake the task of his own free will.”
Chandaka asked that the riverside be converted into a series of pleasure gardens
and then allotted one to each of the Shakya youths. As expected, all the young people came running [to enjoy their new garden plots].
Thus, when one day the Bodhisattva was strolling in his,
a swan fell from the sky and landed palpitating at his feet. It had been struck by one of Devadatta's arrows.
Upon this, Devadatta relayed to him the message:
“Give the swan back to me! It is I who took it first!”
“You were not the first to take it,” Siddhartha retorted, “I took into my heart all the beings of the universe on that day long ago when I first formulated the thought of perfect awakening!”
From that time on, Devadatta's resentment for the Tathagata grew and grew.
King Suprabuddha got a huge crowd of citizens gathered together to remove the colossal tree.
Uttering powerful grunts, these men pressed against the trunk with all their might.
Hearing all the commotion, the Bodhisattva asked Chandaka what was going on.
After his friend explained the circumstances, the Bodhisattva went off with his companions to see what he could do.
A deadly snake lay coiled up in a hole near the tree.
Seeing it lunge out of its nest, and fearing that it might strike the Bodhisattva, a minister's son, Udayi ('Char ka) unsheathed his sword and sliced the viper in two.
Having felt the creature's foul breath, Udayi's complexion darkened.
From that day forward, everyone started calling him Kalodayi (Nag po 'char ka).
The Shakya youths, too, endeavored to move the tree
Putting every ounce of strength to use, Devadatta was able to make the tree shudder slightly,
and Nanda succeeded in lifting it a quarter of an inch or so.
Nobody else could do better.
After that, the Bodhisattva took hold of the tree with just one hand and tossed it into the sky.
The trunk splintered, falling to the ground in two pieces, one on each side of the river.
Cleared, the river started to gurgle and flow.
Siddhartha explained to the gathering: “It appears that this tree's wood has restorative properties which cure bile-related illnesses.
Applied to the skin, the good-hearted tree cures impetigo and boils. Therefore break off a chunk and take it home with you.”
And that is exactly what everyone did.
